thread.title: Russia's Proton rocket flights resume with Inmarsat satellite
thread.title_full: Russia's Proton rocket flights resume with Inmarsat satellite

title: Russia's Proton rocket flights resume with Inmarsat satellite
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sun, Aug 30, 2015, 00:36 BST - UK Markets closed Russia's Proton rocket flights resume with Inmarsat satellite Reuters - UK Focus â€“ Fri, Aug 28, 2015 15:37 BST 0.0001 0.0000 
LONDON, Aug 28 (Reuters) - Russia's Proton carrier rockets resumed flight on Friday with the successful launch from Kazakhstan of one transporting a satellite for British company Inmarsat (Other OTC: IMASF - news ) after the failure of a mission in May. 
The lift off and the separation of three sets of Proton boosters in the early stages of the flight went according to plan, according to mission control commentary. 
Inmarsat's launch slot from the Baikonur Cosmodrome was delayed by the failure of an identical Russian-built Proton rocket carrying a Mexican satellite in May. 
The early stages of a flight are the most risky, but nonetheless Inmarsat said it would not declare the launch a success until later stages were completed, some 15 hours after lift off. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Inmarsat, which supplies communications to shipping, aircraft and remote locations worldwide, jumped after the successful lift off on Friday afternoon. 
They were trading up 4.2 percent at 1422 GMT, at 974.5 pence, topping Britain's FTSE 100 index. 
The satellite -- Inmarsat-5 F3 -- will allow the British company to deploy faster broadband services globally by the end of the year. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is the company's third Global Xpress satellite. 
Chief Executive Rupert Pearce told Reuters on Thursday that the company had worked hard to control any launch risks by performing its own rigorous checks. 
(Reporting by Paul Sandle; Editing by Keith Weir)
